Nitpick: I also just noticed, looking over my pastes above, that the error messages for read-only-permissions and read-only-filesystem differ slightly for some reason:

```
Error loading /tmp/test.dat. Is wallet being used by another process?
Error loading /mnt/test.dat. Is wallet being used by other process?
```

Reproduced.

```
$ stat --format=%Y /home/jon/.bitcoin/wallets/wallet.dat ; shasum /home/jon/.bitcoin/wallets/wallet.dat
1552663315
92a68e8a779c223cc5a66b075a9c8cba7a515627  /home/jon/.bitcoin/wallets/wallet.dat

$ src/bitcoin-wallet -wallet=/home/jon/.bitcoin/wallets/wallet.dat info
Wallet info
[...]

$ stat --format=%Y /home/jon/.bitcoin/wallets/wallet.dat ; shasum /home/jon/.bitcoin/wallets/wallet.dat
1552663564
92a68e8a779c223cc5a66b075a9c8cba7a515627  /home/jon/.bitcoin/wallets/wallet.dat

$ chmod 400 /home/jon/.bitcoin/wallets/wallet.dat
$ src/bitcoin-wallet -wallet=/home/jon/.bitcoin/wallets/wallet.dat info
Error loading /home/jon/.bitcoin/wallets/wallet.dat. Is wallet being used by another process?
```

I've done some preliminary investigation here. To make it work on a read-only filesystem there are multiple issues, at least:

1. Creation of the wallets directory (even if it clearly already exists!)
```
$ src/bitcoin-wallet -regtest -wallet=wallet.dat info
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::filesystem::filesystem_error'
  what():  boost::filesystem::create_directory: Permission denied: "/.../regtest/wallets/database"
```
2. Creation of the lock file `.walletlock`
3. Opening of the database itself in rw mode

Opening the database itself read-only is easier. I've found that replacing `nFlags` in `BerkeleyBatch::BerkeleyBatch` in `wallet/db.cpp` with *just* `DB_RDONLY` is enough to open a database file that has no write permissions for the current user. It succesfully executes the info command.

I suppose to implement this, there will need to be a flag, per `bitcoin-tool` command, whether to open the wallet in read-only or read-write mode. In the first case it needs to bypass (1) and (2) as well.

First attempt at a test to reproduce. I haven't figured out yet how to test `src/bitcoin-wallet info` so used `node.getwalletinfo()` as a proxy. Apologies if this doesn't add value; pointers or guidance welcome. Here is the test output:

```
$ test/functional/wallet_readonly.py 
2019-03-25T13:59:56 (INFO): Initializing test directory /tmp/bitcoin_func_test_j360767k
2019-03-25T13:59:57 (INFO): Fetch wallet file timestamp before getwalletinfo
2019-03-25T13:59:57 (INFO): Wallet file timestamp before getwalletinfo: 1553522397.0744224
2019-03-25T13:59:57 (INFO): Call getwalletinfo
2019-03-25T13:59:57 (INFO): Fetch wallet file timestamp after getwalletinfo
2019-03-25T13:59:57 (INFO): Wallet file timestamp after getwalletinfo: 1553522397.1064227
2019-03-25T13:59:57 (INFO): Assert wallet file timestamp increased
2019-03-25T13:59:57 (INFO): Stopping nodes
2019-03-25T13:59:57 (INFO): Cleaning up /tmp/bitcoin_func_test_j360767k on exit

```

Changing `nFlags` in BerkeleyBatch::BerkeleyBatch in wallet/db.cpp to `DB_RDONLY` does work as described above, but from what I've tried it also breaks the functional tests, so without adding the feature I haven't been able to run the test.
@jonatack There is a `./test/functional/tool_wallet.py` that you could modify
